content: The curr_chunk is a section header titled "SHORT TITLE." The "Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998" requires executive agencies to submit lists of non-inherently governmental activities annually to the Office of Management and Budget. The lists must include details such as the fiscal year the activity first appeared, the number of employees needed, and a contact person for more information. The "Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998" mandates executive agencies to submit lists of non-inherently governmental activities annually to the Office of Management and Budget. The Director of OMB reviews and consults with agency heads on the final list for each fiscal year. Once finalized, the agency head must transmit the list to Congress and make it public, with OMB publishing a notice in the Federal Register. If changes occur due to challenges, the agency head must promptly update the list. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must publish a notice in the Federal Register when the list of non-inherently governmental activities is available to the public. Any changes to the list must also be made public and transmitted to Congress. Executive agencies must use a competitive process when considering contracting with a private sector source for activities on the list. The executive agency must use a competitive process when considering contracting with a private sector source for activities on the list of non-inherently governmental activities. The head of the agency must ensure fair cost comparisons when deciding whether to contract with a private sector source for an activity. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will issue guidance for the administration of this process. SEC. 3. CHALLENGES TO THE LIST. An interested party can challenge the omission or inclusion of an activity on a published list. Interested parties include private sector sources, business associations, and executive agency employees with a direct economic interest in the activity. Interested parties, including private sector sources, business associations, and executive agency employees, can challenge the inclusion or omission of an activity on a published list. Challenges must be submitted to the executive agency within 30 days of the list's publication. Within 28 days of receiving a challenge, the executive agency must make a decision and provide a written notification with the rationale for the decision and information on the right to appeal. Upon receiving a challenge, an official from the executive agency must decide and notify the party with the rationale for the decision and the right to appeal. An interested party can appeal an adverse decision to the head of the executive agency within 10 days, who must then decide on the appeal within 10 days and provide a written notification with the rationale for the decision. SEC. 4. APPLICABILITY. This Act applies to executive agencies including executive departments, military departments, and independent establishments, with exceptions for the General Accounting Office, Government corporations, certain nonappropriated funds instrumentalities, and depot-level maintenance and repair of the Department of Defense. Nonappropriated funds instrumentality refers to a part of a department or agency where all employees are defined in section 2105(c) of title 5, United States Code. Certain depot-level maintenance and repair specifically pertains to the Department of Defense as outlined in section 2460 of title 10, United States Code. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Federal Government source" refers to any organization within an executive agency that uses Federal Government employees to perform an activity. An "inherently governmental function" is a function that is intimately related to the public interest and requires performance by Federal Government employees, including activities that involve discretion in applying Federal Government authority or making value judgments for the Federal Government. The term "inherently governmental function" involves interpreting and executing US laws to bind the government, protect national interests, affect private individuals, control government officers, and manage government property and funds. The term "inherently governmental function" involves ultimate control over US property, including funds. Excluded functions are advisory or ministerial in nature. The Act will be effective on October 1, 1998.
